Description: Gold crescent-shaped ear-ring; thin crescent-shaped sheet of gold bordered with metal wire onto which has been soldered three ivy-leaves in filigree separated by clusters of granulated grapes; the ear-loop is a simple length of gold wire attached to one of the terminals of the crescent and twisted around the opposite side.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Turner Bequest Excavations, Curium
Curator's comments: This is a more elaborate version of a common crescent-shaped type, often dated to the first to third century AD but possibly earlier. See Laffineur 1986, 91 for a discussion illustrated with numerous examples of the plainer forms from Amathus. An example was found at Kourion Ayios Ermoyenis in 1883-4 during excavations sponsored by Col. Falkland Warren on behalf of Lady Annie Brassey (illustrated in Taylor 2001, 224, fig. 22.4). Another direct parallel is GR 1881,8-24.10 from a tomb in Salamis. Bibliography: Laffineur R. 1986, 'L'orfèvrerie', in R. Laffineur et al., Amathonte III. Testimonia 3. Études Chypriotes VII (Paris 1986), 1-142. Taylor L. 2001, 'Lady Brassey, 1870–1886: traveller, writer, collector, educator, woman of means and the fate of her Cypriot artefacts', in ed. V. Tatton-Brown, Cyprus in the 19th century AD. Fact, fancy and fiction (London), 239–47.
Bibliographic references: Jewellery / Catalogue of the Jewellery, Greek, Etruscan, and Roman, in the Departments of Antiquities, British Museum. (2462)
Murray, Smith and Walters 1900 / Excavations in Cyprus (p. 83, Tomb 77 no. 1; Plate XIII & fig. 24.)
